Award.AwardTitle: Genome Engineering a Platform Approach for Biogasoline and Coproducts

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1067730
Gill

Intellectual Merit

There is significant need for fundamental research on next-generation hydrocarbon biofuels that are compatible with the existing fuels infrastructure and meet future greenhouse gas policy requirements. The platform for the proposed research uses engineered microorganisms to produce isopentenol from renewable feedstocks. The isopentenol can then be converted to iso-octane or other co-products using inorganic catalysts. The sustainable microbial production of isopentenol requires a bioprocess that operates at stoichiometric yields, fast rates, and high product concentrations. However, isopentenol flux in current engineered organisms is low, and isopentanol inhibits growth and metabolism at concentrations well below what is required for commercialization.

The engineering of complex traits through the simultaneous and specific manipulation of dozens of genes across multiple pathways has remained an area of intense effort at the forefront of metabolic engineering. The size of mutational space encoded by even the smallest microbial genomes is immense. How nature manages to effectively access this space is not completely understood, and prior efforts in this area have not previously been extended far beyond the level of individual genes or pathways. The proposed research will address the challenge of engineering complex traits through the use of a new genome engineering toolkit. Specifically, the genome engineering toolkit uses a new approach for genome engineering that combines advanced DNA synthesis, recombineering, and genomics to potentially improve upon traditional approaches by several orders of magnitude. The objectives of the proposed research are to: 1) increase flux to isopentenol using rational genome engineering of E. coli strains, 2) map isopentenol tolerance mutations at the genome-scale, and, 3) iteratively optimize performance via combinatorial genome engineering.

Broader Impacts

The basic genome-engineering approach developed for this proposed research has potential for widespread application across all of areas of biotechnology, where engineering of complex phenotypes is an important determinant in cost and life cycle analyses. The educational activities focus on a comprehensive plan for involvement of undergraduate students in biofuels research through the Colorado Center for Biorefining and Biofuels (C2B2) and CU-NREL Renewable and Sustainable Energy Institute (RASEI).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project brought together advanced synthetic biology and metabolic engineering tools for the purpose of engineering sustainable chemicals (and fuels) and training graduate students and postdocs in state of the art technologies. The scientific focus of this project was directed at the further development and integration of novel approaches for engineering complex microbial systems, which rely upon the coordinated action of multiple genes underlying several traits important to production of a target molecule (e.g. isopentenol in this study). In the first Aim we focused on manipulating genes expected to have an affect on flux to isopentenol, while in the second Aim our efforts shift to identifying and then manipulating genes relevant to the cells ability to continue to grow in the presence of isopentenol. The final Aim was then directed at combinging these modifications and assessing the affect on isopentenol production. Major outcomes from these efforts included i) the construction of libraries of isopentenol pathway variants using novel synthetic biology methods, ii) the mapping of isopentenol tolerance mutations using three state of the art genome-mapping strategies spanning all genes in the genome, and iii) screening various libraries from (i) and (ii) for lycopene production via several different strategies. The results from these efforts have been disseminated to the larger scientific community through several peer reviewed publications as well as presentations at scientific meetings. Funding for this project partially supported the training of five PhD students, five postdoctoral researchers, and 2 undergraduate researchers, several of which were from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM subject areas. Several of these young scientists are currently pursuing academic careers.
